Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Automated and community-driven synthesis of the tree of life
Award.AbstractNarration:
The tree of life links all biodiversity through a shared evolutionary history. This project will produce the first online, comprehensive first-draft tree of all 1.8 million named species, accessible to both the public and scientific communities. Assembly of the tree will incorporate previously published results, with strong collaborations between computational and empirical biologists to develop, test and improve methods of data synthesis. This initial tree of life will not be static; instead, we will develop tools for scientists to update and revise the tree as new data come in. Early release of the tree and tools will motivate data sharing and facilitate ongoing synthesis of knowledge.

Biological research of all kinds, including studies of ecological health, environmental change, and human disease, increasingly depends on knowing how species are related to each other. Yet there is no single resource that unites knowledge of the tree of life. Instead, only small parts of the tree are individually available, generally as printed figures in journal articles. This project will provide the global community of scientists who study the tree of life with a means to share and combine their results, and will enable large-scale studies of Earth's biodiversity. It will also create a resource where students, educators and citizens can go to explore and learn about life's evolutionary history.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The tree of life demonstrates the shared evolutionary history of all biodiversity. It is fundamental for the scientific community as a unifying concept and as a tool. Biological research of all kinds, including studies of ecological health, environmental change, and human disease, increasingly depends on knowing how species are related to each other. Yet there is no single resource that unites knowledge of the tree of life. Instead, only small parts of the tree are individually available, generally as printed figures in journal articles. The scale of a complete tree of life is such that the tools for construction are generally not available. Furthermore, many species are known only from name only.

The primary goal of this project was to construct a comprehensive tree of life and in the process generate helpful tools and resources for the scientific community and the public. While data continues to be collected across the tree of life, we aimed to present a rough draft, initial display of the tree of life that could be updated as more data was gathered. The goal was to summarize the products of the broad community of phylogenetic biologists. The Open Tree of Life Project also sought to create tools for automated updates of the tree of life by the community and raise awareness about the tree of life among non-specialists, educators, students and the general public.

The project was able to successfully construct a draft tree of all life (Hinchliff et al. 2015) as well as many necessary tools that will allow for the continued updating of this resource. In total, more than a dozen research articles have been published, almost all of which are in high-impact research journals. Additionally, the developments achieved over the course of the project have led to key insights across the tree of life. For example, not only did we determine means of displaying conflict, but we also generated tools that help to identify conflict in genomic data across the tree of life. These have contributed to countless new insights and is driving new research. . Importantly, in order to analyze the large amount of data available in the form of trees or publicly available sequence data in databases, new methods in analyzing and storing large data sets were developed that have become increasingly utilized by other researchers in diverse fields. Finally, the project has facilitated the further analysis of publicly generated data, increasing the value of this already valuable data

This project has had diverse broader impacts. Software developed as part of the project have been made available through standard open-source portals. Numerous personnel were trained in research techniques during the project, including a postdoctoral associate and many graduate and undergraduate students. Finally, the project has led to the establishment of several international collaborations between researchers in the US and in Mexico, China, the United Kingdom, and Australia.
